title: Andy Murray will find Grand slam wins 'very difficult', says Tim Henman
text:

Former British number one Tim Henman has backed Andy Murray to get back to winning tour tournaments, but thinks five set matches will prove tough for the Scot.



Murray's return to the sport has been gradual - his most recent match was a close fought three set defeat to world no. 12 Fabio Fognini in Shanghai.



But Henman believes that Murray has what it takes to get back to winning tour level events.



“I think Murray will get back to winning tour events,” Henman explained, speaking as part of Jaguar's official vehicle partnership with Wimbledon, which saw the Jaguar ambassadors lead a tennis masterclass for a group of Ace Pace competition winners.

(Image: Getty Images)

“I think the physicality of the best of five set matches will be very difficult.



“But knowing him as I do with his work ethic and determination, if anybody can, it will be him.”



The end to Murray's most recent match was fiery affair, with the Scot accusing Fognini of putting him off in between points.

(Image: Getty Images)



While Murray's return to the top may be gradual, Henman believes that a tweak in playing style may be required if he is to reach his former level.

“We’ve always talked about him being quite reactive rather than proactive,” Henman continued.

“I think the more proactive he can be, making his opponent do the running has to be a good thing - that’ll be a challenge for him.”

Henman, Milos Raonic and Katie Boulter were speaking as part of Jaguar's official vehicle partnership with Wimbledon, which saw the Jaguar ambassadors lead a tennis masterclass for a group of Ace Pace competition winners.

The three pros plus Dan Bloxham, head coach of the All England Club, led a three-station coaching session, helping amateurs to perfect their serve, volley and groundstrokes.



The Jaguar I-PACE recently won the treble at 2019 World Car Awards including World Car of the Year, World Car Design of the Year and World Green Car awards.



For more information about the Jaguar’s partnership with Wimbledon visit https://www.jaguar.co.uk/partnerships/wimbledon.html
description: Henman was speaking about the Scot, who has recently returned from a hip injury, at a Jaguar Masterclass coaching session held at Wimbledon
